author: By Robert Jimison
title: Outrage Over Slain Aid Workers Deepens Democratic Resistance to Arming Israel
description: There is strong bipartisan support for aiding Israel in Congress, but the concerns among Democrats could further bog down an already stalled security aid package for Ukraine and Israel.
content: Outrage over a strike by the Israeli military that killed seven aid workers in Gaza has supercharged resistance among congressional Democrats to sending arms and fresh military funding to Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Justice Department Says It Will Reopen Inquiry Into Realtor Trade Group
description: On Friday, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia made a ruling that opens the door for a renewed investigation into the National Association of Realtors.
content: The Justice Department will reopen an antitrust investigation into the National Association of Realtors, an influential trade group that has held sway over the residential real estate industry for decades. The investigation will focus on whether the group’s rules inflate the cost of selling a home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Friday Briefing
description: The Times’s Jerusalem bureau chief on six months of war between Israel and Hamas.
content: It will be six months this Sunday since the Oct. 7 attacks that started the war between Israel and Hamas. More than 32,000 Palestinians have died, people in Gaza are desperate for aid and dozens of Israeli hostages are still being held there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Some of Trump’s Biggest Political Backers Also Threw Trump Media a Lifeline
description: Two billionaires, a wealthy election denier and a mysterious Russia-linked trust invested in the Trump company long before it went public.
content: Marty Davis, the wealthy Minnesota head of a kitchen countertop manufacturing company, is a steadfast supporter of former President Donald J. Trump. He contributed hundreds of thousands of dollars to help elect Mr. Trump in 2020, and encouraged him to fight to overturn the 2020 election results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Greenblatt
title: Literary Gold From the Gilded Age, in Poster Form
description: For lovers of vintage books and periodicals, “The Art of the Literary Poster” celebrates a vibrant niche in late-19th-century advertising.
content: Trends come and go; one era’s tulip fever is another’s Beanie Baby craze. The vogue for literary posters burned briefly, beginning in 1893 and lasting not much more than a decade. But the body of work it produced often hewed closer to fine art than advertisement, and slyly captured the zeitgeist of the times: a bellwether for the modern man or woman whose fondness for the intellectual enrichment of periodicals like Collier’s and Harper’s Magazine was matched only by an aggressive commitment to physical health and attractiveness. (See Charles Arthur Cox’s rendering of five lithe beauties on a tandem bicycle, leisurely perusing the latest copy of Bearings. Gibson Girls who read!)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: In Australia, a Nation’s Banh Mi Love Affair
description: “We’ll make the best of it here. And they can call it a pork roll.”
content: It is only a slight exaggeration to say that Australia runs on banh mi — the Vietnamese sandwich of a baguette with tangy pickled vegetables, a slick of mayonnaise and your protein of choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: The Market May Have Finally Hit a Real Record, but It Could Be a Problem
description: Robert Shiller, the Nobel laureate, says valuations adjusted for high inflation suggest stock returns for the next decade are likely to be modest.
content: It’s been a splendid run for the market — so emphatically great that in just the first three months of the year, the S&P 500 climbed to record highs on 22 separate days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: A Fate Potentially Guided by a Late Brother’s Hand
description: Tanya Sareen met Joel Adolphson, a former squadron mate of her brother Taj, who had been killed while serving six years earlier.
content: Though Tanya Tanwar Sareen’s brother died in 2015, she feels he had a hand in introducing her to her future husband.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: After 6 Months of War, Some Israelis Ask: Is Netanyahu Dragging It Out?
description: Despite growing pressure from President Biden, the Israeli prime minister appears in no rush to end the war in Gaza. Some think he has political reasons for extending the stasis.
content: Nearly six months since it began, Israel’s war in Gaza is dragging on. So, too, is the tenure of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. In Israel, some are now asking: Are the two linked?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph O. Chapa
title: The Next Frontier? Philosophy in Space.
description: STEM can’t solve all our problems.
content: The window to apply to be a NASA astronaut — a window that opens only about every four years — closes this month, on April 16. Though I’ve submitted an application, I don’t expect to make the cut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: U.S. Employers Added 303,000 Jobs in 39th Straight Month of Growth
description: The March data increased confidence among economists and investors that robust hiring and rising wages can continue to coexist while inflation eases.
content: Another month, another burst of better-than-expected job gains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Women Who Made Art in Japanese Internment Camps Are Getting Their Due
description: A traveling exhibit will focus on the work of three Japanese American women artists, Hisako Hibi, Miki Hayakawa and Miné Okubo.
content: Ibuki Hibi Lee remembers waking up to the sounds of her mother’s paintbrush hitting the canvas in their small New York City apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Thousands in New England Still Without Power After Spring Snowstorm
description: A nor’easter that dumped more than a foot of snow across the region, causing blackouts and flight cancellations, is expected to weaken on Friday, the National Weather Service said.
content: Thousands of customers were still without power in Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont on Friday after a powerful storm system brought springtime snowfall to northern New England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Rats on a Dog
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Dana Rubinstein
title: N.Y.P.D. Officials Deploy Aggressive Use of Force (on Social Media)
description: The department’s leaders frequently go on X to upbraid police critics, from media columnists to elected officials, in a departure from protocol.
content: A newspaper columnist was accused of being “deceitful.” A lawyer and political activist was challenged to show her face at the funeral of a fallen officer. And a city councilwoman became the target of an apparent “vote her out” campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Lawmaker Admits Giving Out Colleagues’ Numbers in ‘Honey Trap’ Scandal
description: William Wragg said he had been scared that a man he met on the Grindr dating app had “compromising things” on him, and apologized for causing “hurt.”
content: The messages targeted politicians, advisers and journalists, and even if some of them struggled to remember ever having met the sender, the texts had accurate personal information. Soon, they became flirtatious. Some came with an explicit image.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Lenihan and Maureen Lenihan Rust
title: Our Mom Is 75. We’re Moving Heaven and Earth for This Eclipse.
description: A total eclipse is worth moving heaven and earth to experience.
content: If all goes according to plan, on Monday, our 75-year-old mother, Nancy, will be settled into a lawn chair in Waco, Texas — some 1,300 miles from her recliner in Las Vegas — and joining a great many other Americans as they put on solar eclipse glasses, tilt their heads up and try to make sense of what’s happening in the heavens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Lou Whittaker, Mountain Adventurer and Entrepreneur, Dies at 95
description: While his identical twin was the first American to summit Everest, he was best known  for his devotion to Mount Rainier, the peak of their youth.
content: Lou Whittaker, a patriarch of the nation’s foremost mountaineering family, who helped to make climbing broadly accessible by building a trusted guide company and creating a tourism industry on Mount Rainier, died on March 24 in Ashford, Wash., a town at the base of that mountain. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Sopan Deb
title: An Overlooked Championship Team’s Final Stop: The White House
description: The all-Black Tennessee A&I basketball team won three back-to-back national championships at the height of the Jim Crow era, but were never invited to the White House. That changed on Friday.
content: When Vice President Kamala Harris greeted Dick Barnett on Friday, he was concise in his response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Near the Epicenter, the Earthquake Rattled Plates and Nerves
description: Some drivers said they were on the road and initially thought they were having car trouble; others said it felt like a bomb.
content: At the Spinning Wheel Diner in Lebanon, N.J., near the epicenter of the earthquake, the servers first heard the china loudly rattling on the metal kitchen shelves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Mercedes-Benz Workers in Alabama Ask for Unionization Vote
description: The United Automobile Workers union is mounting its most ambitious effort to gain an industry foothold beyond Detroit’s Big Three.
content: Workers at a Mercedes-Benz factory in Alabama have petitioned federal officials to hold a vote on whether to join the United Automobile Workers, the union said on Friday, a step forward for its drive to organize workers at car factories in the South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Chace
title: Lynne Reid Banks, Author of ‘The Indian in the Cupboard,’ Dies at 94
description: She explored the struggles of young women in the novel “The L-Shaped Room” but found her biggest success with a children’s book about a magical cupboard.
content: Lynne Reid Banks, a versatile British author who began her writing career with the best-selling feminist novel “The L-Shaped Room” but found her biggest success with the popular children’s book “The Indian in the Cupboard,” died on Thursday in Surrey, England. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: New York Has a Budget Trick to Try on the Federal Government
description: The state hopes to take advantage of Medicaid reimbursement rules to divert federal funds into state coffers.
content: Facing increased Medicaid enrollment and a cash crunch across New York’s health care system, Democrats in Albany hope to employ a maneuver that they say will allow the state to generate billions of dollars a year essentially out of thin air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Urges Egypt and Qatar to Push Hamas on a Hostage and Cease-Fire Deal
description: During a call on Thursday, Mr. Biden also pressed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to make a concerted effort for a deal.
content: President Biden sent messages to the leaders of Egypt and Qatar urging them to increase pressure on Hamas to make a deal with Israel that would result in a temporary cease-fire in Gaza and the release of hostages held there, a senior administration official said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: U.N. Rights Body Calls for a Halt to Arms Transfers to Israel
description: The resolution adds diplomatic weight to international demands to curb the supply of weapons being used in Gaza.
content: The United Nations’ top human rights body adopted a resolution on Friday that calls for all countries to stop supplying arms to Israel and puts its key allies under international scrutiny for possible violations of international humanitarian law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anastasia Tsioulcas
title: Review: A Conductor’s Philharmonic Debut Is a Homecoming
description: Karina Canellakis, a born-and-raised New Yorker, led her hometown orchestra alongside another debut, of the pianist Alice Sara Ott.
content: Recently, there has been more speculation than usual about the future of American orchestras. This week, the 28-year-old conductor Klaus Mäkelä became the youngest music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, and there are openings at a number of the highest-profile ensembles in the country — especially after Esa-Pekka Salonen announced his departure from the San Francisco Symphony in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Baltimore Shipping Channel Will Partially Reopen by End of April, Officials Say
description: The Army Corps of Engineers plans to reopen the channel at full capacity by late May, as officials scramble to resume operations at one of the nation’s busiest ports.
content: A shipping channel in the Baltimore harbor that has remained blocked since last week’s collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge will be partially reopened by the end of April, with full traffic expected to be restored by late May, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Are Milk and Eggs Safe as Bird Flu Spreads?
description: Here’s what we know — and don’t know — about the risk the virus poses in food.
content: A strain of avian influenza that has killed millions of birds in recent years has now been detected in dairy cows in several states, prompting concerns about the safety of the U.S. dairy supply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Campbell Robertson
title: Biden Tells Baltimore: ‘Your Nation Has Your Back’
description: President Biden took an aerial tour of the site of the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge and met with the families of the six victims. The authorities later announced the recovery of a third body.
content: President Biden told the people of Baltimore on Friday that “your nation has your back” as he stood in front of the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge, which was destroyed after a cargo ship plowed through it last week, killing six people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Jayatissa
title: The Rage in ‘Carrie’ Feels More Relevant Than Ever
description: Stephen King’s debut novel, about a bullied girl who gets revenge, used to horrify me. Now I find Carrie’s story inspiring.
content: In “On Writing,” Stephen King’s nonfiction account of his career, he talks about a girl he calls Dodie Franklin. She attended his high school and, he recalls, was often bullied for wearing the same clothes every day. In their sophomore year, on the first day back after Christmas vacation, she came to school wearing newly fashionable clothes with a trendy hairstyle — but the bullying and teasing never stopped. “Her peers had no intention of letting her out of the box they’d put her in,” Mr. King writes. “She was punished for even trying to break free.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: How Much Damage Might a Big Earthquake Do to N.Y.C. Buildings?
description: The earthquake on Friday may have felt like a few light shakes to city residents. It most likely would have been much different if the epicenter was closer.
content: For New York City residents, the earthquake on Friday might have felt like just a few light shakes. But if an earthquake of greater magnitude were to strike much closer to the city, the risk of serious damage could be relatively high.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 5, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, April 5, 2024.
content: The item in Thursday’s “Headline From History” feature about a libel case brought by the writer Oscar Wilde misspelled the title of the nobleman who Wilde was suing. He was the Marquis of Queensberry, not Queensbury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a true story of hope and persistence, and Timothée Chalamet’s recent turn as Willy Wonka.
content: In 2020, Anthony Madu’s dance teacher in Lagos, Nigeria, posted a video of the then 11-year-old student gracefully pirouetting and pulling off grand jetés barefoot in the rain. The video went viral, which led to Anthony receiving a scholarship to study at the prestigious Elmhurst Ballet School in England for seven years. This Disney documentary follows Anthony’s journey as he leaves his family to pursue his dream of becoming a professional dancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Jeanna Smialek
title: New Questions on How a Key Agency Shared Inflation Data
description: A government economist had regular contact with “super users” in finance, records show, at a time when such information keenly interests investors.
content: The Bureau of Labor Statistics shared more information about inflation with Wall Street “super users” than previously disclosed, emails from the agency show. The revelation is likely to prompt further scrutiny of the way the government shares economic data at a time when such information keenly interests investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Michael Rothfeld and Dana Rubinstein
title: F.B.I. Examining Free Airfare Upgrades Received by Adams
description: Federal prosecutors and F.B.I. agents are scrutinizing international flights taken by Mayor Eric Adams of New York aboard Turkey’s national air carrier, Turkish Airlines.
content: Federal authorities investigating Mayor Eric Adams’s campaign fund-raising have been examining valuable flight upgrades they believe he received from Turkish Airlines that elevated him to its highest class of seats available on international trips, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: archipelago
description: This word has appeared in 123 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word archipelago has appeared in 123 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 3 in “How Charles Darwin Found Inspiration on the Cape Verde Islands” by Ben Crair:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxana Popescu
title: $700,000 Homes in Mexico City
description: A sunny two-bedroom in Condesa, a condo for presale in Juarez, and a five-bedroom Spanish colonial house in Cuajimalpa De Morelos.
content: This sunny condominium in Mexico City’s elegant Condesa neighborhood, with spaces for living, working and entertaining, overlooks the treetops of Parque Mexico. Built in 1985 and remodeled in 2004 by the Mexican design and architecture firm HABITACIÓN 116, the residence features honey-colored hardwood floors, double pane windows, quarters for a live-in housekeeper and a flex room that could be converted into an office or third bedroom. The unit, one of two residences on the seventh floor of a mid-rise condominium, comes with two gated parking spaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: She Finally Reunited With Her Father. Then He Was Killed in the Subway.
description: Janna Volz’s father, Jason Volz, was largely absent from her life as he fought addiction. They were rebuilding their relationship when he was pushed to his death on the subway tracks.
content: There is an unfinished wooden dollhouse sitting in the attic of Janna Volz’s mother’s house that her father made for her 8th birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: New York to Pay $17.5 Million for Forcing Removal of Hijabs in Mug Shots
description: New York City reached a settlement in a lawsuit brought by two women who were arrested and made to remove their head coverings by the police before being photographed.
content: New York City has agreed to pay $17.5 million to settle a lawsuit filed by two women who said their rights were violated when they were forced to remove their hijabs before the police took their arrest photographs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyon
title: At the Singles Table, Sparks Flew
description: When they met at the wedding of two good friends, Alexandra Dale and Patrick Kohout discovered they had been born at the same hospital.
content: Like many single people attending friends’ weddings, Alexandra Telford Dale and Patrick John Kohout were each given a rundown of eligible guests attending the June 4, 2022, nuptials of John O’Malley and Samantha Pelcher in Manchester, Vt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What Should I Wear for the Eclipse?
description: Silver sneakers? A spacesuit? Our fashion critic advises a reader on how to dress in theme for a coming eclipse party.
content: It’s human instinct, when celebrating a total solar eclipse — a moment of real darkness in the middle of the afternoon — to want to dress for the occasion. It’s a way of marking its importance and making a memory, along with uttering cool phrases like “the path of totality.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Nilay Patel
description: The April 5, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Nilay Patel. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Thursday in the Park With Bigfoot
description: A publicity effort for the movie “Sasquatch Sunset” had one of the film’s cast members in full sasquatch costume, wandering through Central Park.
content: If you were near the Ramble in Central Park on Thursday afternoon, you might have thought you were in a “Planet of the Apes”-themed episode of “What Would You Do?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Sugar’ Review: In a Lonely Place With Colin Farrell
description: This Apple TV+ mystery celebrates and subverts film noir.
content: This much I can tell you: Colin Farrell plays a private detective in “Sugar.” He has a license. We see it being handed to him and everything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Earthquake Rattles New York and New Jersey, but Does Little Damage
description: An earthquake struck the Northeast on Friday, rippling from Philadelphia to Boston.
content: At a general store in New Jersey, near the epicenter of the earthquake, the sound was so loud that the staff thought a truck had crashed into the building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: Larry David’s Rule Book for How (Not) to Live in Society
description: He’s a wild, monomaniacal jerk. He’s also our greatest interpreter of American manners since Emily Post.
content: Suppose you’re out at brunch and find yourself in a buffet line that a fellow diner does not appear to have noticed. He casually approaches with his plate and tries to serve himself. Do you A. join the hangry mob cursing him or B. rise to this man’s defense, because you can see that he’s holding a plate, which means he already waited in line and is now returning for another helping? If you’re Larry David, not only is the answer B. but the misunderstanding warrants, in your scratchy Brooklyn accent, a triumphant clarification: “That’s not how we do things here in America! We don’t wait for seconds! Never!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Go All-In on Detroit-Style Pizza
description: It’s hard to resist the charred and cheesy edges, a thick and chewy crust and a reverse order of toppings.
content: Good morning. Spring’s sprung and I’m back on the pizza beat after a few months of wintry downtime. What that means: I’m feeding my sourdough starter more regularly. I’ll use it for dough I’ll proof for days and days. And then I’ll spin up some margheritas as a warm-up exercise while I contemplate what pizza obsession I’m going to take up for the rest of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: You Can Still Smoke in Atlantic City Casinos. Workers Want to Ban It.
description: The New Jersey casinos are the last large refuge for smokers in the Northeast, but some employees say their health is at risk.
content: Atlantic City casino workers have tried unsuccessfully for years to persuade New Jersey lawmakers to outlaw smoking on gambling floors. On Friday morning, they took their efforts to court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Erica L. Green
title: Israel Agrees to Open Erez Crossing for Gaza Aid After Biden Pressure
description: Israel has come under rising pressure from U.S. officials and humanitarian agencies to allow more aid into Gaza, amid warnings that famine is looming.
content: Israel has agreed to open another crossing and increase the flow of aid getting into Gaza, a move seemingly aimed at tempering the U.S. president’s growing frustration over the dire humanitarian crisis in the enclave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: There’s an Explosion of Plastic Waste. Big Companies Say ‘We’ve Got This.’
description: Big brands like Procter & Gamble and Nestlé say a new generation of plants will help them meet environmental goals, but the technology is struggling to deliver.
content: By 2025, Nestle promises not to use any plastic in its products that isn’t recyclable. By that same year, L’Oreal says all of its packaging will be “refillable, reusable, recyclable or compostable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donna Kim
title: Knowing She was the One, with Surgical Precision
description: Anika Bieg was ready to swear off dating. Then she met Dr. Olivia Sacks — and after 10 minutes, kissed her.
content: In October 2022, Dr. Olivia Arden Sacks’s professional life as a surgical resident was consumed by long hours, an academic paper, and thoughts about her rotation. But amid all the hard work, she had a moment of clarity: Anika Lynn Bieg was the person she wanted to marry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Will There Be Another Earthquake? Here’s the Forecast for Aftershocks.
description: So far, seismologists have not identified any distinguishing characteristics of a given quake that would warn of an impending larger one.
content: Will the ground around Whitehouse Station, N.J., continue to shake in the coming days? Almost certainly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Rising Oil Prices Reignite Inflation Fears
description: The price of Brent crude rose to a six-month high on Friday, a potential dose of bad news for central bankers and for the White House.
content: The price of Brent crude rose again on Friday, at one point topping $91 a barrel. Growing tensions in the Middle East have pushed the global benchmark to levels last reached in October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Margaret Tynes, Soprano Who Soared in Verdi and Strauss, Dies at 104
description: Because there were few opportunities for Black singers in the U.S., she became a powerhouse in Europe, performing in operas like “Tosca” and “Carmen.”
content: Margaret Tynes, an American soprano who was acclaimed in Europe but neglected in the United States at a time when Black singers were newly breaking into the operatic world, died on March 7 in Silver Spring, Md. She was 104.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: The Era of Klaus Mäkelä, Conducting Phenom, Begins in Chicago
description: On Thursday, the richly talented 28-year-old maestro led the Chicago Symphony Orchestra for the first time since being named its next music director.
content: On Thursday evening, when Klaus Mäkelä came onstage to lead the Chicago Symphony Orchestra for the first time since being named its next music director, he seemed at pains not to bask in the roar that greeted his entrance.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Talking 50 Years of Stephen King
description: On this week’s podcast, we talk to the novelist Grady Hendrix and TV showrunner Damon Lindelof about the work and influence of Stephen King.
content: This month marks the 50th anniversary of the publication of Stephen King’s first novel, “Carrie.” In our original review of the book, the crime columnist Newgate Callendar (actually the music critic Harold Schonberg writing under a pseudonym) wrote, “That this is a first novel is amazing. King writes with the kind of surety normally associated only with veteran writers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Melania Trump Plans to Appear at a Mar-a-Lago Fund-Raiser This Month
description: The former first lady is set to attend an event for the Log Cabin Republicans, marking a return of sorts to the political arena.
content: Melania Trump, who has been mostly absent from public view while her husband, Donald J. Trump, campaigns for president this year, will appear at a fund-raiser at Mar-a-Lago on April 20 for the Log Cabin Republicans, the group’s president said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: Was Today’s Earthquake Connected to the Solar Eclipse?
description: The tidal forces on Earth grow as the sun, moon and Earth begin to align, a configuration that can lead to a solar eclipse. But the results of several studies of the relationship between earthquakes and tides are inconclusive, a geophysicist said.
content: With a total solar eclipse set to pass through the United States on Monday, it is easy to imagine a linkage between unusual events in the heavens and on Earth. But geoscientists were cautious about making such a connection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Rachel Cohn, Whitney Jones, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker, Corey Schreppel and Diane Wong
title: Is A.I. Already Taking Jobs? +A Filmmaker Tries Sora + The XZ Backdoor Caper
description: “I’ve always said if you have a ChatGPT subscription and a hose, you can get very far in this life.”
content: This week we look at how A.I. is affecting jobs. As companies start announcing A.I.-related job cuts and experimenting with customer service bots, economists are placing bets on whether A.I. will lead to major gains for companies and workers. Some are even predicting it will help rebuild the middle class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Standby Cruising: A New Option for Bargain Seekers
description: Are you a flexible traveler? Holland America’s standby cruises may be for you. The cost: $49 a day, excluding fees, taxes and extras. The catch: It might be a hair-raising, last-minute scramble.
content: In February, Barb McGowan took a seven-day cruise on Holland America Line, visiting the Bahamas, Turks and Caicos, and the Dominican Republic for just $343, or $49 a day, excluding taxes, port fees and extras. By comparison, Holland America currently lists a seven-day Caribbean itinerary in October from about $700.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Will A.I. Break the Internet? Or Save It?
description: Nilay Patel discusses the near-future of an internet as A.I.-generated content improves.
content: The internet is in decay. Do a Google search, and there are so many websites now filled with slapdash content contorted just to rank highly in the algorithm. Facebook, YouTube, X and TikTok all used to feel more fun and surprising. And all these once-great media companies have been folding or shedding staff members, unable to find a business model that works.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘Girls State,’ ‘Boys State’ and Democracy Through the Eyes of Teenagers
description: Though both documentaries follow programs for rising high school seniors, their differences speak volumes about the challenges the participants face.
content: Documentaries about the American political system are legion, and grow every week. You can bet we’ll be seeing dozens more by the time this year’s presidential election rolls around. But “Boys State” (Apple TV+), the 2020 documentary directed by Amanda McBaine and Jesse Moss, came at government from a different and very refreshing angle. That film chronicles a few participants in the Boys State program run by the American Legion in Texas and every other state except Hawaii. It’s an immersive mock government approach, designed to give rising high school seniors a taste of campaigns, diplomacy and the structure of American government.

content: A barefaced woman studies her reflection, trying on fabric bibs that could have been yanked from a production of “Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat.” In a video posted on TikTok last month, she is draped in lustrous silver, faint pink, a deep green that recalls a jalapeño pepper.

title: Chief Justice Extols Legacy of Sandra Day O’Connor

content: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. delivered a fond tribute to former Justice Sandra Day O’Connor on Thursday, celebrating her legacy as the first woman on the Supreme Court and her commitment to advancing civics and civility after her retirement.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Twenty-six minutes.

title: Is Larry David the Most Unsung Fashion Critic of Our Time?

content: In a midseries episode of “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” Larry David, the HBO show’s star and creator, greets his No. 1 frenemy, Susie, (Susie Essman), who has turned up at a fancy gathering wearing a top hat and a morning coat.

title: How Does Dev Patel Become an Action Star? By Directing Himself.

content: Ten years ago, when Dev Patel started thinking about making the film that would eventually become his feature directing debut, “Monkey Man,” he was not getting offered roles that, in his words, had “any sort of ass kickery involved or coolness.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Birth Dearth and the Smartphone Age

content: My newsroom colleagues Jason Horowitz and Gaia Pianigiani have a lovely report this week about family-friendly policies in the Italian province of Alto Adige-South Tyrol, which has the highest birthrate of any region in an aging, depopulating Italy.

content: Florentino Pérez had a contented smile on his face, and with good reason. He had just watched Spain and Brazil share a thrilling, freewheeling draw at the stadium he has expensively, lavishly, reappointed. Now, Pérez, Real Madrid’s all-powerful president, found himself in a whitewashed tunnel, presented — completely by chance, obviously — with his favorite kind of photo opportunity.

Kennedy Jr. has emerged as a wild card of the 2024 election, attracting a motley mix of ideologically diverse supporters, raising piles of cash and drawing legal attacks from Democrats and verbal barrages from former President Donald J. Trump.

content: When Caitlin Clark, the 22-year-old University of Iowa point guard, lines up against the University of Connecticut team on Friday night, she will most likely shoot the ball from far past the 3-point line. content: I name my houseplants after movie characters that die. That way, if they don’t survive, it’s less tragic and more like a plotline.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Bumpy Gourd That’s Winning Over Bartenders
description: In bars from Hong Kong to Vancouver, the medicinal tang of bitter melon is making its way onto drinks menus.
content: Austin Hennelly, the 35-year-old bar director at Kato, a Taiwanese restaurant in Los Angeles, likens tasting bitter melon to “going down the drop of a roller coaster.” Sipping the fruit’s juice — which is the star ingredient in his Garden Tonic, a mocktail he considers the best drink on Kato’s menu — is, he says, “a little bit unpleasant and maybe a little bit scary, but it’s exhilarating, and then you just want to do it again.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tell Us What Your Man Cave Means to You

content: It evokes beer fridges and car parts, Super Bowl ads and maybe even Jerry Seinfeld’s bachelor pad, where he displayed his 17 favorite cereal boxes on a shelf. It’s the man cave: punchline, poker hub and perennial source of masculine escape.

content: A grandmother taken captive during the Oct. 7 attack on Israel probably was killed when an Israeli helicopter, responding to the Hamas-led assault, fired on the vehicle in which she was being held, Israel’s military said on Friday.

content: On one chilly evening in March, after the sun had set and when most school-aged children were begrudgingly starting their homework, Felicia Dawkins, 16, enthusiastically hopped on the phone from Scotland to share that her life had changed — for the better.

title: Prisoners Who Sued Over Lockdown Will Be Allowed to View Solar Eclipse
description: The six inmates at an upstate New York prison had said the eclipse was “a religious event that they must witness.” A statewide prison lockdown will remain in place.
content: New York State’s corrections department agreed on Thursday to allow six men who had sued to be able to view Monday’s total solar eclipse to do so at the upstate prison where they are held, but the department stopped short of lifting a statewide prison lockdown during the eclipse.

author: By Peter Coy
title: If A.I. Takes All Our Jobs, Will It Also Take Our Purpose?
description: Life without problems to solve sounds great until it starts sounding awful.
content: What would life be like if artificial intelligence solved all your problems? You wouldn’t have to work anymore. You could get any luxury you wanted by raising an eyebrow. Feelings of pleasure would wash over you constantly. Death would become almost optional because you could take on digital form and keep going for a billion years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Dwindling Ammunition Stocks Pose Grave Threat to Ukraine

title: China’s Young People Are Giving Up on Saving for Retirement

content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

source.name: The New York Times

title: Who Will Pay for the Baltimore Bridge Collapse?
description: Disputes over liability and the cost of claims could take years for insurers to resolve and result in billions of dollars in payouts.
content: On the day the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore collapsed, President Biden said the federal government would pay the “entire cost” of rebuilding it, which some suggest could run to more than $1 billion. source.name: The New York Times

title: Variety: Acrostic

content: ACROSTIC — Today’s puzzle is a reminder of the total solar eclipse that is expected to shroud parts of Mexico, Canada and the United States in darkness on April 8. The solution is a passage from a book called “Sun, Moon, Earth: The History of Solar Eclipses From Omens of Doom to Einstein and Exoplanets,” by Dr. Tyler Nordgren, an astronomer whose enthusiasm for the phenomenon is infectious enough that I regret choosing to stay home a little and settle for a partial, 90 percent eclipse. I hope that everyone who will see it in its totality, including Mr. Balton and Ms. Stewart, gets clear skies!

title: A ‘Taxi Driver’ Remake: Why Arthur Jafa Recast the Scorsese Ending
description: The artist has gone back to his filmmaking roots, re-examining what he sees as racial undertones in Martin Scorsese’s classic 1976 movie.
content: Call it a return to his roots. The artist Arthur Jafa began his career as a cinematographer, working with his then-wife, Julie Dash, on the acclaimed “Daughters of the Dust” (1991) and with Spike Lee on “Crooklyn” (1994), before garnering art world fame, including a Golden Lion at the 2019 Venice Biennale, for  “The White Album,”  created from original and collaged video footage. title: In the End, ‘The New Look’ Left Us Wanting More

content: The last episode of “The New Look,” the Apple TV+ series about Christian Dior, Coco Chanel and the birth of post-World War II fashion, aired on April 4. content: I was recently at a family gathering and, in the course of the conversation, casually mentioned that I had always wanted to take a DNA test and find out more about the background of our family history. When I said that, my cousin reacted strongly, saying that she didn’t want any family member to take one and have their DNA in the hands of an organization or government that might use it with malicious intent. She feels uncomfortable with having related DNA in the system, because she worries this data will somehow triangulate back to her. She has not committed any crimes, but for her this is a serious privacy issue. My family is small, and my cousin has always been my closest family member. We speak several times a week, so taking the test and hiding it from her feels wrong, but I’m not sure if her wishes in this case override mine. How much am I required to consider her feelings about this? — Name Withheld
